instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7010: What is D7010? Diode between ground and gate of Q7010 on 2013-2015 year retina model macbook pros, necessary for Q7010 to allow PPDCIN_G3H to flow through to PP3V42_G3H power supply input. When this diode dies or corrodes, PP3V42_G3H input will not have any voltage, and chargers will not turn on. This can often be the problem if a system only works with a knockoff charger/bench power supply. .
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.820-00138A: What is 820-00138A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light appear every few second
threads.message:
I have this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, my own board who died a long time ago, time to repair it
when I plug in magsafe, it there's a green light but only a momentary, and it would appear a few second later, im using a magsafe 2 85w 
is there any chance the problem is still my magsafe ?
I don't have pp 20v at the fuse, tried changing dc in already

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light appear every few second
threads.message:
Probably original charger detects leakage and doesn't want to power up the board.
Usually <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR>, or <DIODE>D7010</DIODE> issue.
Post exact value of <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR>; ohm scale, measured onboard.

Does it start with desk power supply, or fake charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light appear every few second
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> and <DIODE>D7010</DIODE> looks fine though
<RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> measured by probing each end is 22.06k
sorry no access to desk psu and fake charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light appear every few second
threads.message:
"<TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> and <DIODE>D7010</DIODE> looks fine though"
What this means, are they photogenic?
Do you have a DMM to check them???
Post exact ohm value for <RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR>/81 and <RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR>/86, measured onboard.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light appear every few second
threads.message: Im sorry to ignore the question, but I have 1 other board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which is 2015 15" retina I think, so the magsafe doesnt turn on at that board too, my magsafe is 85w, but, I heard from rossmann videos if the cable is from 60w, is it still doesnt work ? if its, I will find another real magsafe 2 85w first..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light appear every few second
threads.message:
You should get G3H and S5 voltages at least; even with 45W charger.
And board should charge battery and start with battery and any charger connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light appear every few second
threads.message: So changing <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> give me steady green light, but im such an idiot, i remove the smc and accidentally mixed it up with other smc, so i want to ask, if I try to test smc 1 by 1, how can I know if the smc doesnt match? Any measurement i can make?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light appear every few second
threads.message:
You must be sure to get SMC from same board model.
You can test all SMC one by one, untill get fully working board; supposing original SMC is good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light appear every few second
threads.message: so I place this smc, It give me green and then amber light, i try usb mouse and i got usb activity , and then i hooked it up to external monitor and I have an image, booting fine, should i troubleshoot no video problem or this can be wrong smc ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light appear every few second
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light appear every few second
threads.message: Hi, i just realize this board doesnt have serial number ( clock set right, active internet connection). I have been told to use hex editor, but I don't really know how, any tutorial on changing serial number?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light appear every few second
threads.message:
Many threads on the forum for the same issue.
You should got an idea already.
Replacing Fsys area into another (clean ME) BIOS, with the one from your backup BIOS, should solve the problem.

Upload your backup somewhere; if you cannot do it by yourself.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light appear every few second
threads.message: I have tried reading fsys from original bios to medusa but i got an error when trying to write fsys to new clean me bios. The problem is i want to learn how to edit serial number, in case the original bios is gone, after that i will fix checksum with the medusa

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light appear every few second
threads.message:
If you just swap entire Fsys area, no need to fix checksum.
Original serial number of the board is preserved.

If you need to change serial number, do it with HxD editor.
Then fix checksum, after BIOS has been flashed on the Mac ROM.
